The bug hurdles are fridge space and upfront cost. It's too big to just put in your refrigerator so you either need a kegerator or some kind of dedicated fridge. Add in a keg, lines, fittings, a co2 tank, regular, tap/Faucet. It all adds up.

posts.com: Where I go hiking, it's Bear Mountain in the Hudson valley, there's a ton of blueberry bushes. Also, you can go to Palisades Park on the Jersey side if you want to find a ton of Mulberry trees and dewberry bushes. You can identify the latter by the fact that they look like blackberries and grow on a low trailing shrub. I've gone hiking hungry and went home full, that's how many berries there are. Just make sure you inspect your berries closely so you don't eat any bugs. I have really good eyesight and a single bug has never gotten past me. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18942559
Longjing grown in the official designated region starts at around $800lb maybe a bit more, and goes up to eye wateringly high prices. The tea probably isn't worth it, ive had good longjing style teas that were 16¢ per gram or so. The main reason it's so expensive is that it is a very popular and prestigious gift that is valued highly in Chinese gifting culture where they consider the high price to be a positive thing to show how valuable their gift is. Unfortunately lots of the very high end of Chinese teas are subject to this gifting culture price inflation so the prices won't necessarily reflect their value as a tea drinking experience. There are also some teas like silver needle white tea where the grading and value is based totally on the appearance and size of the buds and the actual taste of the tea falls fairly low on the the list of qualities the tea is priced and judged for. That's why it's important to have a decent understanding of Chinese teas before you start throwing money around in the upper price categories of tea. As with most luxury commodities expensive doesn't always = better.

The only exceptions are spring veg (hop shoots, asparagus, may cauliflower, spring onions, baby carrots, first radishes, bear garlic) and mushroom dishes.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18930663
I got one of those Zojirushi Japanese rice cookers and it's become one of my favorite kitchen items.

There's the obvious benefits:
Rice is always cooked perfect, better than I do in a pot, it's easier, I can't mess it up, and the cleanup is easier.

But the really big one that you don't realize until you have one is that it's fire and forget. Before you start cooking you load it up and start it and you never have to worry about the rice again until you need it. This thing cooks the rice perfect by itself and then can keep it warm and at perfect consistency for over 12 fucking hours. When you need the rice you just open it up and scoop it out.

Also it plays twinkle twinkle little star to let me know when the rice is done. (Japan you silly.)

>>18938271

Polishing is supposed to make your 2500 edge last a tad longer. Since a knife's edge is basically made of a lot of pointy spikes, a grit past 2000 makes them smaller and thus hold their shape better. They will just be more efficient longer by just using a strop or one of those honing rods, which straighten the spikes that gent bent (but not dulled) after use. Chefs would probably sharpen their knifes around every 2 to 3 weeks but these guys go theough literal tons of vegetables and meats per month and also need something that is razor sharp all the time. Meaning you could easily stay a few months without any sharpening as long as you regulary strop

>1500 will get shaving with skill

this is true. i went so far down the sharpening rabbit hole a few years back that I got into straight razors. if you are going to sharpen a straight razor that you intend to shave with, you should be able to do 20 passes per side on a low grit stone (400-600) and have it cutting hair afterwards. otherwise, you aren't good at sharpening, and you should work on your technique.

of course, quality straight razors don't require a steady hand to hold an angle. you literally just lay one side flat on the stone, do your strokes, and then flip & repeat. the key is to use the same pressure for each side.

If you really insist on reprofiling your dull ass knives then yeah sure, invest in a shitty two faced stone with low grit face like 200, 400 and a slightly better grit like 600 or 800. Sure, it'll take a while, 15 mins per knife, but once the edge is redone, a few passes every month will suffice.

You only really just need one sharp knife if you're a home cook. The rest is just mental masturbation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18942670
Single bevel? If it is you need to make sure your stone is super flat to work the ura. The front side is either flat or slightly curved. You need to form a burr on the front and then remove it from the other side. After that you use light pressure to refine the edge.

If your knife is double beveled use your fingernail to feel for a gap between the stone and edge. Gently increase the angle until you just can't feel the gap between stone and edge.

2 or 3 fingers on the edge and a firm pinch grip on the handle. Do a few swipes on the stone and recheck your angle using the fingernail test. Checking consistently will help you improve by showing you if you have held the angle consistently.

Eventually you can actually feel if you have the bevel on the stone properly, but that is quite difficult and requires a lot of experience.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18942854
You will need to feel and observe to see. Sometimes the blade road has a slight curve to it. Try that fingernail trick I was describing.

The other trick you can try is to observe how the blade undercuts the water on your stone.

You do an edge leading stroke and look to see if water flows over the edge. The blade undercuts the water. This trick also helps show you how sharp your knife is on the stone you're using. As your edge gets closer to the max your stone will give you without any burr the undercut will get more and more pronounced.

You need to use sandpaper backed by something like hard rubber or wood if you're talking about polishing the flats. Do the tightest progression you can and remove the handle if possible. You won't be able to make it look perfect if you can remove the handle.

At the final grit of sandpaper do strokes perfectly straight from handle to tip so the scratch pattern is straight and consistent.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18942899
Oh.. nice a masamoto yani. Pretty nice knives I have a big one.

So sandpaper the flat where the runes are. For the blade road/shinogi you can work a progression of stones. They need to be flat, and you need to be consistent along the entire length of blade.

Once you get up to a high grit you should use finger stones to even out the polish and create good contrast between the hard steel and cladding.

>stone
6 months to 1 year, only when you notice substantial sharpness loss, unless something stupid happens and you chip the edge etc.
>strop
Generally only after using stone, to remove the burr, or much like the stone as needed for edge deformations that are perceptible but not enough to bother with the stone.
>hone
A few strokes before every time you use your knife.

Do this and your knives will be razor sharp for ever.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18943168
I have a KANGZ 1000/6000 and it's definitely great for an affordable price.

Be warned though, 1000 grit means any knife that you haven't sharpened before may take a lot of time to get there. I highly suggest you also buy a lower grit stone to ease your way into 1000. usually, a chinese noname brand does the trick. Other retards will suggest other one faced stones but a the 6000 face grit gets you something as sharp is it can get. Also, all stones pretty much last a lifetime.

Again, the first sharpening may be a pain in the ass but once that is done you'll never have to spend more than 5 minutes on a knife. Definitely more like a minute.

Just make sure you dry your stone after use, by leaving it slightly leaning on a wall for example.

Title: The Social Media Cleanse

Act 1:
Jerry, Elaine, George, and Kramer are sitting in Monk's Cafe, each of them glued to their smartphones, scrolling through their social media feeds. Jerry complains about how he can't seem to escape the constant barrage of political news, and George laments about his ex-girlfriend who won't stop tagging him in memes. Kramer, on the other hand, brags about his 10,000 followers on Instagram.

Act 2:
Elaine announces that she is going on a social media cleanse to clear her head and improve her mental health. The group initially scoffs at the idea, but after Elaine begins to show signs of improvement, they all decide to join her. They vow to stay off social media for a week.

Act 3:
The group quickly realizes how difficult it is to abstain from social media. Jerry becomes obsessed with the number of likes on his posts, George struggles to resist the urge to stalk his ex-girlfriend, and Kramer experiences severe FOMO (fear of missing out).

Act 4:
Elaine is the only one who manages to stay true to the cleanse, and she begins to feel more peaceful and present in her daily life. She encourages her friends to stick with it, but they all eventually cave in to the pressure of social media.

Act 5:
As the week comes to an end, the group reflects on their experience. Jerry admits that social media has taken over his life, and he needs to set some boundaries. George realizes that he needs to let go of his ex-girlfriend and move on, and Kramer decides to delete his Instagram account altogether. Elaine is proud of herself for completing the cleanse and feels empowered to continue living a social media-free life.

Reminder that 95% of scotch distilleries are owned by multi-national corporations, import barley from countries overseas such as Turkey and Egypt, do the malting offsite, buy peat from other regions of Britain, use lab-created yeast for their mash, use barrels made from American or Spanish wood, and add caramel coloring to the final product.

The only thing authentic about any particular region or scotch distillery is the water or copper stills, both of which could hardly be said to contribute any unique flavor profile to the scotch over any other distillery.

The only thing that gives a scotch an authentically unique flavor profile that is not imported from elsewhere is the process by which the components are put together, i.e. smoked peat, grain ratios, etc. This is a process, which has nothing to do with utilizing the resources of the terroir.

All of this wouldn't be so bad if it wasn't for the over-insistence that each distillery possesses a unique terroir. French wine for example has much stricter requirements for the definition of something like Champagne. If the grapes don't come from Champagne, it is not Champagne.

You are buying a good that is being sold to you as a goodgoy lifestyle product, like a bottle of Armani cologne. There is nothing uniquely Scottish to a bottle of scotch whisky in 2023. LVMH (French):
Ardbeg, Glenmorangie

Diageo (English):
Johnnier Walker, Talisker, Lagavulin, Caol Ila

Beam Suntory (Japan):
Laphroaig, Ardmore, Auchentoshan, Bowmore

Pernod Ricard (France):
Aberlour, Strathclyde, Glenlivet, Scapa, Lomond, Chivas

Remy Cointreau (France):
Bruichladdich, Octomore, Port Charlotte

Distell (Africa):
Bunnahabhain
Glenblair

Emperador (Phillipines [lol]):
Dalmore, Jura

That enough for you, faggot? Wow, sure are a lot of authentically, wholly-owned Scottish companies in that list, huh? And you really believe international mega-corporations aren't going to cut corners to fulfill the obligation to their shareholders?

The majority of barley is imported through Port Ellen (owned by Diageo), 80-90% of which is foreign import. It is germinated and malted onsite at Port Ellen. As for the barrels, check the websites of any scotch brands and find me a single one not made with American, Spanish or French oak, I dare you. Caramel coloring is not only a reality of scotch production but actually *sanctioned* by the British government - check the regulations yourself. That authentic peat flavor you bloviate about endlessly can comes from Aberdeenshire - the literal other side of the country from Islay. Considering the distribution of peat worldwide, it would be of no surprise to me if this was imported from Eastern Europe as well.

So that whittles down the contribution of individual distilleries to their copper stills, their water and their process.

Please, enlighten me, what have I said that is *blatantly wrong*? That Champagne is not made in Champagne? Or that multi-billion dollar corporations aren't going to dump a fortune into marketing to losers like you?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Nose: Burned chicken in gravy, wood smoke, overheating electronics, marmite and malt out of the bottle, upon first uncorking. Hints of anise and candy-apple subsequently appear. In the glass, the apple and burning electrical equipment dominate, with new notes of hospital disinfectant and wood glue.
>Taste: Wood smoke, creamy caramel, oak, burned chicken without gravy, a hint of peach, citrus, malt and apple. Almost no burn going down at all.
>Finish: More smoke, tobacco, and wood glue.
>Verdict: My favorite scotch and favorite alcoholic drink of any kind. I was expecting Laphroaig 10 to be a peat-dominant, savory, malty scotch before trying it, but in fact it is a whole trifecta, straddling all of the three major flavor profile categories of scotch - it manages to have wonderful rich confectionery and fruit notes, better than those found in most other whiskies I've had, in addition to all the peated flavors. My dream scotch would be a dry, earthy dram like Dewar's White Label but with much more complexity, strength and smoke in it, and whilst this did not end up fitting that bill, it is an absolutely excellent whisky.

>Nose: Alcohol, and not the good kind. Primarily some kind of paint stripper, maybe with a dead rat left in it for good measure. On the second pass, after the tears had cleared from my eyes, I get desinfectant, weed killer and a hint of mustard gas. Amazing, how can something be this much of a punch to the nose with only 40% abv?
>Palate: What the....? As a lifelong atheist, Im not one to resort to religious ejaculations, but I'll make an exception in this case: Jesus F'ing Chirst what is this? My tongue is trying to flee down the back of my throat, the roof of my mouth is on fire, and my lips are considering a change in career. This tastes like somehting the kids came up with while playing with their chemistry kits. Words escape me, and after a while, the first to come back are "cadaverous", "vile", "rotting", "toxic".
>Finish: Oh, if only it were finished, but of course, it's long, monumentally long, just to drag out the torture. I remember getting a nasty sunburn as a kid, and if that had been on the inside of my mouth, I'm sure that's how it would taste and feel. That'll teach you to not use sunscreen - I'd honestly prefer a mouth full of sunscreen right now. Gasoline fumes rising from my esophagus, with a sidenote of that brown juice that drips out of the bottom of a compost heap. Please stop.
>Overall: Do people actually drink and enjoy this stuff? Or is it just some elaborate joke to take the piss out of newbs like me? I'll be heading back to the Highlands as far as whisky is concerned, and I'll think long and hard before considering another trip to Islay.

ok here are some tips
make the layers thin, hinner than you hink
check every layer before taking it out of he oven, literally made two yares back to back same iime and hickness same batter first one was perfect, second one was raw but it looked perfect, it baked on op but was completely raw at the bottom
be really careful with them, i baked it again but it completely los its shape, lucky for me i needed one layer to crumb for decoration
while we are at it dont, geting the exra layer to harden enouh to crumb is hard as fuck, it starts burning while still soft at the center, i ended up pulling it out, crumbling it as it was and then baking the crumbs abd thats when i fucked up my thumb
buy cheap homey cookies and use those instead, bake them so they brown, it makes 0 difference as you dont really taste the cake crumbs anyways
wai until every layer cools off completely before assembling it, get the cream really cold before whipping, have some extra cream on hand in case you run out by the time you have to decorate the cake
its way sweeter than you expect i to be and its ok if the cream inside is bland, its even better as the cake is exremely flavorful
geting the crumbs to stick o the sides is pretty difficult, cream isnt sticky enough, hell if i were to make he cake again i would replace the cream covering the cake with italian meringue

>>18937646
>It's double the price but not double the size. So no, it doesn't really make sense.
On the Lodge website, the 12" is $30, and the 13.25" is $50. Their most common model is the $10.25", which is regularly $24 and currently marked down to $20. One of the reasons cast iron, in general, is not popular is due to the weight. We can see that the 12", at 7.89 lbs, is 47% heavier than the 10.25" (5.35 lbs), and the 13.25", at 10.5 lbs, is 100% heavier than the 10.25" skillet. So based on weight, there is TWICE the iron in the 13.25 inch skillet as in the 10.25 inch skillet--you might have had some inkling of this if you understood the difference between diameter and area of a circle.

Based on material alone, the regular price of the 10.25" being half of the 13.25" makes sense. However, you'd be stupid if you thought that was the only factor. Because the 10.25" is more popular, more stores are going to order them reliably. Lodge can make more of them, without worrying if they will sell and receive a return on their investment. It's the one model that they know they won't have leftover stock at the end of the year; therefore, they can afford to sell them with thinner margins. Hence the $20 price right now.

So basically, you're a complete idiot and you should feel bad about it.

>>18942489
basically you can do anything with them other than washing them in a dish washer. Dish soap will not harm your seasoning, the idea you can't use soap on your cast iron was back when it was made with Lye. Rough or smooth doesn't really matter outside of aesthetics, really the only thing that matters on the seasoning is using an oil or fat with a high smoke point if you want to make reverse sear meme steaks where you need to get the skillet to 500 degrees.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Also, if your'e using your cast iron pan daily (or every other or so day), there is no need to be paranoid and to wash them after every use.
Just leave the food particles and seasoning on it and put it away inside of the oven, or on top of the stove, (but don't put lid on it), let the air dry the stuff out, and just use it when you're ready.

I used to wipe them out with a paper towel, (but almost never used water to wash it with).
But for the last few years I have 8 inch cast iron pan that I use it twice a day, (morning and evening), and I don't even wipe it anymore.
Just scraping the food with a spoon, and I'm leaving it on top of the stove, (again, no lid on it).

BTW,
go to used stuff store and buy size matching clear glass lids from those glass pots.
They work great on cast iron pans.
Of course if you live in a shithole where you have swarms of flies flying like chinese balloons in your kitchen then you can not leave it on top of the stove.
Just put the fucker inside of the stove.

I know, some primitive paranoid faggottss will become suicidal after reading this, but those who have brains try it.
Nothing fucking bad will happen to it, no need to be cleaning freak all the time.
I'm doing this for like almost 10 years now, it's just small particles of dried food and spices.

>>18942369
>expensive enameled shit,
BTW,
for this uneducated pleb.
Cast iron enamelled pans are preferable if you are concerned with too much iron "leaking" into your food, especially if you are preparing acid forming foods, like tomatoes, etc.
Of course frying eggs on enamelled pans is not as easy as is on "bare" cast iron.
Eggs, (and some other foods), will stick to enamelled surfaces.
Eggs will just slide right off from the "bare" cast iron surface pan.
But as always, main thing is to make sure that you pre-heat your pans before you put food into them, regardless what material they are made of.

I like using enamelled cast iron pans for stewing veggies or meat.
They keep heat for so long that when the food is 50% or 75% done, I just turn the heat off and let it cook on till is done.
Have another one, enamelled, 10" x 3 " deep.
The one in the picture is 10" x 2" deep.
Put glass lid on it and you're set.

>>18942677
>Worth the price tag
I mean... not really over the run of the entire line, but that's because the usefulness to price ratio really tapers off hard with things like a rice cooker. If you're just looking at something that might do 4 cups at a time with a really minimal layout, you might as well spend the extra $20 or so and get a good one - the heater and latches will probably last longer on it, more than likely worth it. If you're going for something capable of cooking mass amounts of rice with a bunch of bells and whistles, maybe take an inventory of your needs vs wants first.

>I'm trying to eat healthier
It depends on what's unhealthy about your diet. If the problem is pre-diabetes or basically anything else resulting from too much carbohydrate intake or not enough vitamin/protein/lipids, eating rice with every meal isn't going to help that.

>>18943432
It doesn't take much to keep rice above 140F/60C. The benefit of people not vomiting and shitting themselves to death with B Cereus poisoning outweighs the handful of watts per hour used to keep rice warm while everything else finishes cooking. Here's your (you).

>>18943462
It's the amps that count with induction - on one hand a 120 volt system (vs 240) means that your amperage has to double, which should make the induction slightly more efficient - the end goal basically being a hard step down of voltage and sharp step up of amperage over the AC coil jump between induction coil and the pot. BUT, if the device isn't designed with the higher input amperage in mind, you might burn out components more frequently.

>>18942677
When I lived in Japan, I had a Zojirushi and I could cook a shitload of rice on Monday, then leave it on "warm" for like the next 2 days, and the rice would be perfectly fine as I ate it througout the week. When I came back home to the US, I got a "made in Japan" Zojirushi that was intended for the US market, and the warm mode was limited to only about 8 hours before the fucking thing automatically switched back to high heat and dehydrated my rice. I couldn't even have decent rice the next morning for breakfast.

When I dug into the specs of the various US models, I found that there are some higher tier models that let you keep a longer warm mode, but all are gimped with some sort of time limit. The one I had in Japan literally had no limit at all.

tl;dr, no, they are not worth it. Just learn to steam rice or boil it on your stovetop. It's not hard.

>For something more familiar to western pallettes but arguably more disgusting, start putting back straight mayonnaise, which is essentially just egg yolks and oil, and thus pure fat, with very small amounts of anything else. Close to 800 cal per 100gr, if you make your own extra fatty version, but be warned that stuff like Hellmann's is more like 720cal, and don't get me started on shit like Miracle Whip at a measly 300-ish.
>If you can't handle these by slice or the spoonful, you'll want them on the minimal acceptable amount of something like extra dry, low moisture crackers to maximize carb-to-weight, or even better, crackers with a high fat content; Ritz crackers clock in at about 480cal per 100gr compared to 400cal for the same amount of pure sugar.
>An option safely inside the tasty zone would be macadamia nuts, clocking in at just around 75% fat with the rest being almost entirely carbs and protein with nearly no water; very efficient for something so appealing! Trying to go higher than that without being revolting can be very tough tough, but at 720cal per 100gr, it blows the pants off having to sit there with a spoon and a jar of store-bought mayonnaise... for most, at least.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18947014
And for those wondering, salo/mayo on Ritz crackers gets beaten out by pure macadamia nuts once you're using more than 26gr of Ritz crackers per 100gr of salo/mayo. Higher calorie density crackers/bread/etc. would let you use more, but Ritz are the first thing that popped into my head and I don't know if there's something readily available with more density.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18946636
Butter

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18946636
Probably crystalized glucose (such as crystalized corn syrup) would be the densest source of calories by weight. More so than other sugars and starches because calories are expended to convert them to glucose.

In terms of a food with the most calorie density thermodynamically, it appears to be paraffin (edible and still eaten) or vegetable oils and surprisingly not ethanol. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy_density#In_chemical_reactions_(oxidation)

posts.com:
>>18942754
Curry is a great one pot meal, coupled with microwave rice or naan and you are good for the week. Stores in jars perfectly, just nuke rice and curry and done.

Chili mac is a good one to make: both meat and carbs to keep you going. Also keeps in jars and is nukable. Straight chili also works.

Stews would also be a portable solution for when you get tired of the above. You can also do a ragu (meat or stock version) and premix with pasta to have jarred ready to heat meals. Couple with some grocery bread for the road.

Strogenoff also keeps reasonably well.

You can also do rice stir fry type meals and stick them in the bigger food prep containers if you want less calories.

Plus you can always carry some frozen items to mix it up.

>>18942754
here's what I do and it comes out pretty good. it's a bulking meal prep

>box of protein pasta
>2c cottage cheese
>2lb chicken breast
>spinach
>1lb ground turkey
>jar of marinara sauce
>1/2 jar of alfredo sauce
>small carton of egg whites

basically just cook everything and mix it together, add the egg whites to the cooked turkey, add the pasta and sauces to the turkey, dice the chicken, cook it, then add it to the pot, and finally blend the cottage cheese until it's smooth and pour it in. then add spinach.
it lasts me almost the whole week

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18940012
(Sockeye) salmon nigiri with wasabi only. I hate seeing retarded almost-weebs mixing wasabi into their soy sauce, or even just using soy sauce at all DESU. Also funny to see them putting it on the rice instead of the fish.

That's my go-to, but I also love hamachi (though it's usually expensive), ebi, and toro. Negitoro is my favorite maki, and it's usually what I order first to judge the quality of the restaurant I'm at. I also occasionally indulge in the new age shit like volcano rolls and dynamite rolls. I think crushed tempura batter is a great addition to sushi if you're looking for something tasty but not super classic. Better yet, aburi is fantastic as it adds depth, so long as the chef is careful to not cook the meat and only torch the outside. Aburi and beef tartare are definitely the things to order from a higher dollar Japanese/French fusion place (several in Vancouver and probably elsewhere). Pretty fantastic

>>18936140
1) Take any root vegetable and slice it thin. (Of course give yourself a firm base by slicing in half first) (Most are fine to just scrub with a brush but leave unpeeled -- plenty of flavor and nutrients, and you're not serving at a restaurant.)
2) Pat slices relatively dry with paper or cloth. If the veg has a lot of moisture, you can draw it out with some salt or in the microwave at low heat, but I've never found it necessary.
3) brush with oil of choice (or toss in it if particularly porous, like lotus root), season, then put it in a medium-hot pan. Alternatively, bake the fuckers. With an online recipe remember these are thin as fuck, so you need to cook slower at lower heat or they will burn.
4) Give them a few minutes til they're lightly brown, then flip them, then transfer them to a rack or just right on a plate. There's no more oil in these chips than you would use in an air fryer, so there's no need for a drain step, and they're so thin that they're cool quick enough just fine directly on a plate -- thus you should eat them pretty soon after cooking if you want them hot and chewy.
4 alt.) Alternatively, go *really* low and slow in the oven until they are mostly dried out, and brittle, more like potato crisps.

Again, pretty much any root veg works for this. As part of testing out a root veg I haven't tried before, I usually make a small batch of these, among other things.

>>18942141
the way I do any cream of vegetable soup is just grill onions, then add whatever veg you want (in your case mushroom and cauliflower or broccoli would be good, better to leave cabbage for a stew) grill for a bit, then add couple cups of stock or water and bring to a simmer. Let simmer until everything's nice and soft, then let it cool a few minutes before blending it (immersion blender is easiest but you can also add it to a blender, just make sure it's not too hot or it might explode out the blender.)
Then you finally add whatever thickener you're using and heat it back up before serving

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18946473
I have a canned jar of chicken that I bought from Walmart that lasts 7 years past when I bought it. If you pressure can meat and hermetically seal it, it'll last until the proteins and fats literally decay on their own independent of microbes. I would consider 5 years a baseline, 10 years optimistic, after that point fats will start to denature. I don't want to meme but look at Steve1989mreinfo videos and hes basically a Guinea pig for food preservation to the point where he can tell you the tastes and sensations to watch out for when eating old foods to tell what components have degraded.

. when you fry the eggs, you grabb a tea spoon and sprinkle hot oil over the yolk, untill it turns full pink, and the egg whites are completely done. By that point the egg is ready.

I've been rendering enough lard lately that using it as cooking fat no longer did the trick so I figured I'd try to make shortcrust pastry and make some meat pies. All of this was done on a whim so the filling was whatever I had available: small diced pork loin, minced onion, a little dark beer and some flour to thicken it up during cooking. It turned out decent taste-wise and the pastry itself was flaky enough but as you can see it doesn't look very good. I know an egg or milk wash would've helped with the color but how do I avoid it overflowing like that? Draping the pastry more loosely over the filling? I could've cooked the filling first but I've seen plenty cornwall pasty recipes and the filling is raw. Anyway, thoughts? tips? insults?

Also the macros are not great. How much fat can I remove from your classic shortcrust recipe before it starts fucking with the texture? I've seen some recipe use an egg, does that help?

Feel free to post your own hand pies to dunk on me as well. Hand pie general

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18946478

>Cook filling
>Fold in pastry
>Beat egg yolk with some salt
>Brush over pastry
>Bake until golden

Mind you, I did have some success making pie crust with olive oil for quiches before, but the texture is completely different, it's not flaky at all. I obviously will keep testing with less fat, I just thought I'd ask for some outside opinions

>Screwdriver
That's hardly a cocktail. That's spiked OJ. But I'll forgive you, since the other two are fine choices. Except a half a lemon in your sour? I'd think you were making a highball again but with only the dash of s.s., I'm wondering if you're just not juicing the lemon well enough.

If you have a hand squeeze juicer, make sure the technique is correct. If reaming, use a fork and puncture the shit out of the base of your half lemon, the hold it in and gently twist around in there while squeezing the lemon - it should basically disintegrate.

My favorite cocktail is still probably an Old Fashioned if I could just figure out how to make it correctly.

posts.com: I'll say this about G&Ts and classic martinis: even though modern gins (unaged, neutral-base, classic/contemporary style) are really really good, even to people who don't normally like gin, the old-school basic cocktails were made with stuff like Gordon's and Bombay Classic, which are bottom-shelf today. In the original Vesper (James Bond's vodka martini) he specified Gordon's gin, ffs. My point is that for my own mixing currently I have two go-to gins: Gordon's and New Amsterdam (contemp, not their vile London dry), the cheapest stuff out there for totally smooth juniper-forward and citrus-forward-no-juniper. (Kirkland and Bombay Classic are also nice juniper-forward at a similar price). I have some nicer gins -- an import bottle and a lot of nips -- that I keep around when I want to experiment with martinis or new bitters (for pink gin), but for right now, as someone still relatively new to all this, I'm recommending people who are ok with the juniper-forward taste to just do mixing with Gordon's and NA (or instead of the latter any contemporary you can find at a steal deal -- NA is rather pathetic as a "gin", but it certainly is a better sub in any vodka cocktail).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18941510
It still improves frozen pizza if you use a pizza stone, you can preheat your pizza stone nice and hot to like 500F, then throw your frozen pizza on it and turn the oven temp down to whatever temp the pizza normally cooks at (so you don't burn your toppings) and then just keep an eye on it and when the cheese is fully melted and looking your preferred color of golden//brown if you prefer things cooked a bit extra.

Takes a bit longer to preheat, but cooks in ~10-12 minutes instead of 18-22.

End result is a much crisper crust underneath and a less floppy pizza.

>>18944726
Pic related is underrated and only common in northern Germany.
Cut pork shoulder or neck in pieces slightly smaller than a fist
Season with salt, black pepper, a ton of allspice and some clove, bay leaves and juniper
Saute the chunks in pork fat, clarified butter or neutral oil
Take the meat out and add finely sliced onions and also saute them
Add some tomato paste and toast it
Deglace with either water, beer or imo the best: Veal fond and add some bay leaves
Add the meat back in and cook until the onions have dissolved and thickened the sauce and the meat is tender
Before serving season the sauce with the spices above to taste and thicken it with starch if it's not thick enough. Some also add mustard.
Serve with potatoes, red cabbage and a pils.

Very rustic, but simple to make, cheap and very flavourful. The meat becomes extremely tender just like pulled pork.

tacos al pastor gringo style

posts.com:
>>18946133
>carrot sauce?
There are few ways to make it depending on your country of origin, but most involve sauteing chopped onion with shredded carrots and either parsnip or turnip in butter or lard then adding flour to make it into a roux. Stock is added, chicken or veg, and the roux dissolved. Finally, it's blitzed smooth.
I just use onions, carrot juice and stock cube instead, still making the roux and blitzing the onions into the sauce smooth. Most recipes also add cream, either sour or fresh, and prepared mustard near the end.
The process is
Par-cook the pork on both sides
Remove from the pan
Add the veg and cooking fat
Cook
Add the flour
Make roux
Add powdered caraway
Add the stock (or juice+cube)
Dissolve roux
Blitz smooth
Re-add pork
Finish in the sauce
Add cream, mustard and fresh dill (i just use dill, not the other two)
Serve with a starch. Bread. Bread dumplings. American-style stuffing. Pasta (hate it with pasta, but it's a thing; look up csirke vadas spaghettival). Whatever. Just not potatoes. Idky, but no.

>>18940730
That's definitely too long unless it's sitting in the fridge. At room temperature yeast will eat most of what it can and then die around 12-14 hours later. Though too much yeast is also a potential problem, especially if it's the instant dry stuff.
Also, if you're doing a single long fermentation, you'll need to fold ("punch") the dough a few times through, which will redistribute the yeast and its food, release some of that gas which is actually toxic to the yeast, and relax your gluten.

>>18941977
I used 6 C flour (plus some depending on what the dough wants)
1-2 tsp. salt(fine)
made well after mixing dry with a fork then added:
1 ¾C water + ½C half and half heated to 115°
2 tsp. raw sugar
1 heaping tsp. yeast from the jar
and 6Tbsp melted butter (I used a whole stick, the remaining went into buttering the pans.
kneaded until smooth,
let rise until doubled,
Whacked the bubbles outta the dough and rolled it into the standard loaf shape for the pan
(Two folds, then fold in the ends with a pinch)
slit the tops 3x then brushed with last of the butter,
375°F oven, middle shelf for 26 mins.

I make the baugette style too and sometimes the freeform bowl dump kind.
ALL BREADS ARE GUD BREADS when you make them yourself.
I French bread Pidzers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I went to a snake restaurant in China. They had these black snakes in cages. they chopped them into pieces a couple of inches wide, and served them in a bubbling hot pot with lots of chillies, ginger and garlic. The skin was chewy, but not unpleasantly so. There was no meat, it was bone and skin. The skin was ok to be honest, but I'd never order it or go there again.
I also ate softshell turtle. It was a delicacy and, in that region, traditionally it was eaten every Chinese New Year kind of like how white people have turkey at Christmas. It had some meat, and was served in a bubbling brown stew with vegetables. I was told the cartilage or some part or other was especially good, but to me it was another bony, unsatisfying meat.
What was good was bullfrog. People say things taste like chicken, but that actually does taste like chicken. Slightly fishy chicken. Meaty and delicious. They toss it in flour and fry it, then take those crispy bits and fry those again with some vegetable, and serve it in a dry hot pot.
